It is located in the [[Notre-Dame-de-GrÃ¢ce]] area of the borough of [[CÃ´te-des-NeigesâNotre-Dame-de-GrÃ¢ce]] in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], [[Canada]] {{cite web|title= Villa-Maria Metro Station|url= http://www.stm.info/English/metro/a-m48.htm |publisher= SociÃ©tÃ© de transport de MontrÃ©al|accessdate= 2009-07-11}}. == Overview == The station is a normal [[side platform]] station, and has an entrance at its south end. The entrance is located in a bus loop. The station was designed by [[AndrÃ© LÃ©onard]] and contains [[mural]] [[sculpture]]s by the architect. ==Origin of name== Villa-Maria station takes its name from the nearby [[Villa Maria (school)]] school, which in turn takes its name from the [[Latin]] House of Mary. The surrounding lands were once owned by the Decarie family. The land was sold in 1795 to Sir James Monk and the Monk residence built in 1804. This is the central section of the present-day Villa Maria school. In 1844, the building was leased to the Crown as a residence for the [[Governor-General of Canada|Governors-Generals]] of Canada. ([[Charles Metcalfe, 1st Baron Metcalfe|Lord Metcalfe]], [[Charles Cathcart, 2nd Earl Cathcart|Earl Cathcart]], and [[James Bruce, 8th Earl of Elgin|Lord Elgin]] all resided on the Monklands.) The property became a country hotel for five years, after which time it was purchased by the nuns of Congregation-de-Notre-Dame in 1854, who turned it into a private girls school which they named Villa Maria.
